title: Mindful Breathing
summary: Focus your attention on your breath to anchor yourself in the present moment.

details.content: Mindful breathing helps calm the mind, reduce stress, and increase awareness of the present moment. It is a foundational mindfulness practice that can be used anytime, anywhere.
When feeling anxious before a test, you pause, close your eyes, and focus on the sensation of your breath entering and leaving your body for a few minutes.

content: Sit or stand comfortably with your back straight.
Bring your attention to your breath, noticing each inhale and exhale.
If your mind wanders, gently bring it back to your breath.
Practice for 1-5 minutes to start, gradually increasing the duration.

title: Body Scan Meditation
summary: Systematically bring awareness to different parts of your body to promote relaxation and self-awareness.

details.content: Body scan meditation helps you notice physical sensations, release tension, and connect with your body. It can reduce stress and improve your ability to respond to discomfort.
Lying in bed, you slowly move your attention from your toes to your head, noticing sensations without judgment.

content: Find a quiet place and lie down or sit comfortably.
Start at your toes and work your way up, noticing sensations in each body part.
If you notice tension or discomfort, acknowledge it without trying to change it.
Spend 10-20 seconds on each area, moving slowly and mindfully.

title: Mindful Walking
summary: Walk slowly and pay attention to the sensations of movement and contact with the ground.

details.content: Mindful walking integrates mindfulness into daily life, helping you stay present and grounded. It can be especially helpful if sitting meditation is difficult.
During a walk in the park, you focus on the feeling of your feet touching the ground and the rhythm of your steps.

content: Walk slowly and deliberately, paying attention to each step.
Notice the sensations in your feet, legs, and body as you move.
If your mind wanders, gently return your focus to the act of walking.
Try practicing for 5-10 minutes in a quiet space.

title: Loving-Kindness Meditation
summary: Cultivate feelings of compassion and goodwill toward yourself and others.

details.content: Loving-kindness meditation can increase empathy, reduce negative emotions, and improve relationships. It helps foster a sense of connection and well-being.
You silently repeat phrases like 'May I be happy, may I be healthy' for yourself, then extend those wishes to friends, family, and even people you find difficult.

content: Sit comfortably and close your eyes.
Begin by offering kind wishes to yourself.
Gradually extend these wishes to others: loved ones, acquaintances, and all beings.
Use simple phrases such as 'May you be safe, may you be happy.'

title: Mindful Listening
summary: Listen to others with full attention, without judgment or interruption.

details.content: Mindful listening improves communication, deepens relationships, and helps you understand others more fully. It reduces misunderstandings and increases empathy.
During a conversation with a friend, you focus completely on their words and emotions, resisting the urge to plan your response.

content: Give the speaker your full attention, making eye contact if appropriate.
Notice your own reactions and thoughts, but return your focus to the speaker.
Avoid interrupting or judging what is being said.
Reflect back what you heard to show understanding.

title: Mindful Eating
summary: Eat slowly and pay attention to the flavors, textures, and sensations of your food.

details.content: Mindful eating helps you enjoy your food more, recognize hunger and fullness cues, and develop a healthier relationship with eating.
At lunch, you take small bites, chew slowly, and notice the taste and texture of each mouthful.

content: Eat without distractions like TV or phones.
Take small bites and chew slowly.
Notice the colors, smells, and flavors of your food.
Pause between bites to check in with your hunger and fullness.

title: Gratitude Practice
summary: Regularly reflect on and appreciate the positive aspects of your life.

details.content: Practicing gratitude can boost mood, increase resilience, and help you focus on what is going well, even during tough times.
Each night, you write down three things you are grateful for, such as a supportive friend or a beautiful sunset.

content: Set aside a few minutes daily to reflect on things you appreciate.
Write your gratitudes in a journal or share them with someone.
Be specific—focus on small, everyday moments.
Notice how this practice affects your mood over time.
